div.p: DIALOGUE, BETWEEN A Fond FATHER and his little SON.

p.hi: Deſigned to amuſe and inſtruct Children.

WHEREAS a Dialogue between a Father and Son, printed ſome time ago, met with a ſpeedy ſale, and was thought of ſome advantage, 'tis now thought that a continuation of ſaid Dialogue, may be ſtill more advantageous, and it is committed to the preſs for that purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p:
DEAR Son, you remember that ſome conſiderable time ago, we took a rambling walk through the orchards, fields and meadows, and cloſe by the ſide of the river, where we took a view of the bridges, mills and falls, and proceeded down the ſtream until it emptied itſelf into the ocean, where the great ſhips traverſe the main, and go round the world, which is above twenty thouſand miles, or as the ſhips muſt ſail, to go round the
different capes of land, it will be above forty thouſand miles, before they can get back to the place from whence they ſat out.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: I very well remember that agreeable walk, and ſhould be glad to take another ſuch, if you would go with me.—But I never could underſtand how the ſhips could go round the world, when there is ſo much land as well as water.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p:
Dear ſon, it is not ſtrange that you ſhould not fully underſtand it, for there are many men that cannot fully comprehend it. But when you are older and have read ſome books on geography, and had an opportunity alſo to ſee a terreſtial globe, where the globe is divided into land and water, and where the tract of Lord
Arſon and Capt. Cook, is marked out on the globe, you may eaſily conceive how they may go round the world, and return again to the place from which they ſat out.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: Truly ſir, I think it would be a very pleaſing ſtudy, and I hope that I ſhall ſoon be ready to begin it, for I ſhould be greatly pleaſed to ſee how the globe is divided into land and water, and to ſee where the different nations of the world live, and whether they be black or white, heathen or chriſtian, and what is the produce and manufacture of the different parts of the world.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: 'Tis truly a very agreeble ſtudy, and at a proper time I ſhall be glad to inſtruct you therein, but at preſent we will defer it, and talk of ſomething elſe.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: Well ſir I am willing to be directed by you, as you know what will be moſt uſeful and beneficial to me.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Since the time that we took that agreeable walk, you are become older and bigger, and I hope have read and learned a good deal.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: Sir I have read ſome little ſtory books wrote for the inſtruction of children, ſuch as the Mother's gift, the Father's legacy to his children, the Child's Inſtructor, and Children's Friend, &c. I have alſo read ſome little hiſtories of the Bible.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Have you not alſo read the bible.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I have read it through and through again, and ſome parts of it I have read many times.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Then I hope you remember a good deal that you have read.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: I hope that I remember ſome, but truly my memory is ſo poor, that I do not remember half ſo much as I wiſh I did.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: What do you remember to have read in the Bible.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: I remember that in the beginning God created the world, the heavens and the earth, the ſun, moon and ſtars, and the ſea, and all in the ſpace of ſix days, and reſted from his labour on the ſeventh, which was the ſabbath.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Do you not alſo remember that God made man.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: Yes, I remember that it is ſaid, that God made man out of the duſt of the earth, and breathed into him the breath of life, and he became a living ſoul.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: After God had made man where did he live.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: We read that he was placed in the garden of Eden, which is alſo called the garden of Paradiſe.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Was he to live there alone.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: No, we read that God ſaid it was not good that man ſhould be alone, and he cauſed a deep ſleep to fall on Adam, and he took out one of his ribs, of which he made a woman, and brought her to Adam to ſee what he would call her, and he called her Eve, for ſhe was bone of his bone, and fleſh of his fleſh, and ſhe became his wife.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: What were they to be employed about in the garden.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p:
We read that they were to cultivate and till the ground,
and take care of the fruit trees, herbs, &c.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Had they liberty to eat of all the fruit trees in the garden.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: We read that they had liberty to eat of all except one, which was the tree of knowledge and of good and evil, which they were not to eat of, upon the 〈◊〉 of death.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: And was they 〈◊〉 as to eat of that tree, which God had commanded them that they ſhould not eat.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p:
Yes ſir, we read that the ſerpent (or the devil) ſaid unto the woman, that ſhe ſhould not ſurely die if ſhe eat of that true, but that they ſhould be as Gods, to know good and evil, and to ſhe 〈◊〉 to the temptation, and 〈◊〉 of the fruit and did eat, and 〈◊〉
unto her huſband and he did eat.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: And what was the conſequence.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: Why we read that their eyes were opened, and they knew that they were naked, and had ſined, and they endeavoured to hide themſelves from the preſence of God, among the trees of the garden.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Did God after this ſuffer them to continue in the garden.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: No, we read that God turned them out of the garden, and placed a flaming ſword to prevent their return, and God curſed the earth in conſequence of their ſining, and ſaid, that it ſhould bring forth briars and thorns, and that men ſhould earn their bread with the ſweat of their brows, until they ſhould again return to the earth.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Had Adam and Eve any children.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: Yes, they had Cain and Abel, of whom we read that Cain was a wicked boy, and Abel a good boy, and when they were grown up Cain was angry with his brother Abel, and when they were in the field, he roſe up againſt him and ſlew him.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: And was not God angry with Cain for killing his brother.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: It is ſaid, that God was very angry with him, and told him that he ſhould be a vagabond upon the earth, and that every one who ſound him ſhould ſlay him; and Cain ſaid, that his puniſhment was greater than he could bear, and God ſet a mark upon him, leaſt any finding him ſhould ſlay him.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Did mankind multiply upon the earth after this.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: Yes, they multiplied and 〈…〉 very numerous.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: 〈◊〉 as the people generally good and virtuous, or very ſinful.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: We read in the bible that mankind became very ſinful, and by their ſins and wickedneſs, provoked God to anger.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: And what was the conſequence of the world becoming 〈◊〉 wicked.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: We read that the great God was very angry with them, and threatened to crown the world, and deſtroy mankind, unleſs they repeated and became good.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: And did not mankind in general grow better and repent after God and ſo threatened them.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p:
No, we read that they ſtill continued wicked, except Noah and his family, and God bid Noah
build an Ark, by which he and his family and ſome of all ſorts of creatures, might be preſerved and ſaved alive, when the reſt of the world ſhould be drowned.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: How long was Noah in building the Ark.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: We read that he was many years in building it, for it was a very great building, with many apartments; it was three ſtories high, and made to accommodate all that was to be taken into it.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Was not Noah called a preacher of righteousneſs to the people.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: Yes, he is ſo called in the Bible, and I ſuppoſe he preached to the people, and warned them to repent and become good, or they would all be deſtroyed.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: And did 〈◊〉 the people regard 〈◊〉 , and attend to his 〈◊〉 .

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: No, they went on in their old way until the fatal day in which the rain began to fall, and Noah & his family, and two and two of all creatures went into the Ark, and the doors and windows were cloſed, and no man ſuffered to go in, and ſo they were all drowned.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: How long did the flood prevail on the earth.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: We read that it rained forty days and forty nights, and the fountain of the great deep was broken up.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: And how did Noah know when the waters were abated on the earth.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p:
We read that the waters prevailed on the earth 150 days, but after 40 days Noah opened a window and let out a dove, who after flying about and finding no place to reſt her feet upon, ſhe returned
to Noah and he took her again into the Art; and then he waited ſeven days more, and let her go out again, and after a while ſhe returned with an olive leaf in her mouth plucked off, by which Noah ſuppoſed the waters were abated, and after ſeven days more be let out the dove again and ſhe never returned, and after a while the Ark reſted on a great mountain called Ararat.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: How long was this flood upon the face of the earth.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: We read that in the ſixth hundred and firſt year of Noah, the firſt month and firſt day of the month, the waters were dried from off the face of the earth, and Noah and his family, and all the creatures in the Ark went out upon the dry land.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: What now become of Noah and his family.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: We read that God made a covenant with him, and it was confirmed by a rainbow, that the earth ſhould not again be drowned.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: After the flood, was the poſterity of Noah all good, or did the people again be wicked.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: We read that they again become very wicked, and thought in their pride to build a great tower, that ſhould reach up to heaven, and God was angry, and came down and deſtroyed their language, ſo that they could not underſtand each other, and ſo they were ſcattered upon the face of the earth.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: But was there no good people in all this time, did not God make ſome diſcovery of Chriſt the Saviour, who was to come into the world.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p:
Yes, we read that ſoon after the fall of man, God ſaid, that
the ſeed of the woman ſhould bruiſe the ſerpents head; but I never knew the true meaning of that ſentence.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Why the meaning of that text is generally ſuppoſed to be, that a Saviour, the Meſſiah, ſhould come into this world, and make ſatisfaction for the ſins of man, and ſo deſtroy the works of Satan, and thereby prepare the way for man to be finally ſaved.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: Was there any further prophecy of the Meſſiah, who was to come into the world.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p:
Yes, there were many prophecies and intimations thereof, to Noah, Abraham, Iſaac, and Jacob, to David, Iſaiah, and other Prophets of old, and all the ſacrifices of beaſts and birds, &c. that we read of in the old teſtament, are ſuppoſed to look forward to that
great and atoneing ſacrifice that ſhould be made for ſin, by Jeſus Chriſt the Meſſiah, and Saviour of the world; and eſpecially by the type of the brazen Serpent, that was erected in the wilderneſs, which the children of Iſrael were directed to look to, when they had been bitten by the flying fiery ſerpents.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: And did the Meſſiah truly come into the world, agreeable to the prophecy and expectation of the people, who were looking and waiting for the accompliſhment of theſe prophecies.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Yes, in the fulneſs of time, namely, at about the four thouſandth year of the world, the Meſſiah made his appearance to the Jews and the world.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p:
And did not the Jews, (God's ancient people,) expect him as a temporal king, and that he
would be uſhered into the world in great pomp and ſplendor, and that he would deliver them from their bondage to the Romans.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Yes, truly this was their expectations, and they were greatly diſappointed when they found that he rather took on him the form of a ſervant, and was poor and deſpiſed in the world.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: Where was Chriſt's firſt appearance in the world.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: He was born at Bethlehem, and was found with his mother Mary in a ſtable, there being no room for them in the inn.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: Was there any intimation to any body, of the Meſſiah being born into the world.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p:
As the ſhepherds were ſeeding their flocks, an angel appeared unto them and told them that the Meſſiah who had been
long expected, was born into the world; and the ſhepherds were diſpoſed to go and ſee him, and pay their worſhip and adoration unto him, and alſo the wiſe men of the Eaſt, enquired where Chriſt ſhould be born, and they were directed by the appearance of a ſtar in the Heavens, that went before them, and ſtood over the place where the child Jeſus was.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: And did they find as the Angel had told them.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Yes, they found the child Jeſus and his mother Mary at Bethlehem, laying in a manger, and they rejoiced and praiſed God that there was a Saviour born into the world.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: Did not King Herod deſire the wiſe men when they returned, to tell him where they found him, that he might alſo go and worſhip him.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Yes he did, but his deſign was to 〈…〉 was afraid that he would become a king and take away his kingdom.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: And did the wiſe men of the Eaſt, return and inform the King Herod.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: No, they returned another way and to diſappointed him, and he was ſo angry that he ordered all the children from two years old and under to be 〈◊〉 ; but Mary with her child Jeſus, went into Egypt, and ſo eſcaped his hand.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: Was there any thing extraordinary that appeared in Chriſt Jeſus whilſt he was young.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p:
We read in the Bible, that he kept with his parents, and was ſubject to them;—but when he was twelve years old he was found in the temple, aſking queſtions
of the doctors, and giving anſwers beyond what could be expected from one of his age; and he aſked his parents if they did not know that he muſt be about his father's buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: What is ſaid of him when he became a man.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p:
He became a preacher, and ſpeak as never man ſpake before; and he went about doing good, healing the ſick, reſtoring the lame, giving ſight to the blind; he fed many thouſands with a few loaves and fiſhes, and raiſed ſome to life again who had been dead, and did many miracles, ſo that thouſands flocked after him to be healed of their diſeaſes of ſoul and body, and they brought little children to him, and his diſciples forbad them, but he told them to come, for of ſuch he ſaid was the
kingdom of God, and he took them up in his arms and bleſſed them.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: What doctrine did he preach, or what advice did he give to the people that came to him.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: He told them that they were ſinners, and that they muſt repent of their ſins, and believe on Jeſus Chriſt if they would be ſaved.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: What is meant by repentance.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: You have learned your Catechiſm, which tells you what repentance is.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p:
I remember it is ſaid, Repentance unto life is a ſaving grace, whereby a ſinner out of a true ſenſe of his ſin, and apprehenſion of the mercy of God, in Jeſus Chriſt, doth with grief and hatred thereof, turn from it
unto God, with full purpoſe and endeavours after new obedience.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Don't you alſo remember the anſwer to the queſtion, "What is faith in Jeſus Chriſt?"

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: Yes, the anſwer ſays, That ſaith in Jeſus Chriſt is a ſaving grace, whereby we receive and reſt upon him alone for ſalvation, as he is offered in the goſpel.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: But is this all that we are to do, in order to be ſaved and go to Heaven.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p:
Truly, I believe that thoſe who repent and believe on Chriſt, will not fail of being ſaved and going to Heaven; but they who have true faith and repentance will be diſpoſed to good works, and to hate every wicked and falſe way, to do as they would be done by, and attend unto all the rules
and precepts of the goſpel, to fear God and keep his command, and live ſoberly, rationally, and Godly, in this world.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: Is it not of free grace that any are ſaved.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Surely it is, and whoſoever is ſaved will be ready to acknowledge, that it is all grace from the foundation to the top ſtone.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: Truly I am obliged to you, for the good inſtruction given me, and I can ſay as King Agrippa ſaid to Paul, thou almoſt perſuadeſt me to be a Chriſtian.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: And I can as truly ſay as St. Paul, I wiſh that you was not only almoſt but altogether perſuaded to be a Chriſtian, that ſo after ſerving God, and your generation according to his will, you might go to Heaven and be eternally bleſſed and happy.

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p: But is it worth while for children and young ſolks to be religious, and to put on the Chriſtian name.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p:
Surely it is well worth while, and it highly becomes all, both young and old, to profeſs and practice the Chriſtian.—Hear what the great poet, and good man, Dr. Young, ſays;—
"A Chriſtian is the higheſt ſtile of man,
"And is there who the bleſſed croſs wipes off
"As a foul blot from his diſhonour'd brow?
"If angels tremble, 'tis at ſuch a ſight:
"The wretch they quit, deſponding of their charge,
"More ſtruck with grief, or wonder, who can tell?"

sp.speaker: Son.
sp.p:
I thank you for your inſtruction
and kind advice, and hope I may have wiſdom and grace to follow it.

sp.speaker: Father.
sp.p: Dear Son, if you do truly ſo hope, you will be willing from your heart to join in the following PRAYER.

Oh Lord God, have mercy on me in Jeſus Chriſt thy dear Son; and for his ſake pardon all my ſins, and accept of me (a poor ſinful child,) as righteous in thy ſight. Make me a Chriſtian indeed, and help me to live a ſober and religious life, that my latter end may be that of the righteous, and my eternity happy.— AMEN.

div.p: Entertaining Extracts, From various Authors. Worthy the peruſal of every good Child.

l.hi: Learning advances men of mean degree,
To high attainments, wealth, and dignity.

div.head: EXTRACTS, &c.
div.p:
THE bittereſt things in religion are ſweet; there is a ſweetneſs even in reproofs; when God meets with our corruptions, and whiſpers unto us, ſuch and ſuch things are dangerous; and that if we cheriſh them, they will bring us to hell, the word of God is ſweet to a chriſtian, that hath his heart under his innocence; is not pardon ſweet to a condemand man, and riches ſweet to a poor man, and favor ſweet to a man in diſgrace, and liberty ſweet to a man in captivity? ſo all that 〈◊〉
from God is ſweet to a chriſtian, that hath his heart touched with the ſenſe of ſin.

div.head: ORIGIN OF SHIPPING.

q.hi: And God ſaid to Noah, make thee an ark of Gopher wood; rooms ſhalt thou make in the ark, and ſhalt pitch it within, and without, with pitch.

div.p:
THE moſt ingenious and uſeful arts are of celeſtial origin; and from this chapter it is evident, that the firſt ſhip that ever floated on the world of waters, was built according to the plan, and under the regulating eye, of a divine artificer. With what amazing contrivance and oeconomy were the directions given by the Deity to Noah? How exact the architecture, and what judicious hints were hence furniſhed to human creatures in regard
to maritime affairs! Man has always been characteriſed by his powers of imitation. From this very ark aroſe the firſt ideas of a poſſibility to paſs beyond the limits of land: the ſcheme once projected, and the ſecret of its conſtruction once imparted, it was not likely to be forgotten; ſo far otherwiſe, that we ſtand indebted to it, for many valuable bleſſings —for the advantages of commerce, the pleaſure of travel, and the glory of victory. The merchant and the ſailor owe to this undertaking all their benefits; and whatever deſirable circumſtances ariſe from connections with remote climates, certainly originate from an imitation of that ſacred repoſitory, which preſerved from the deluge the family of Noah.

div.head: OF COMPANY.
div.p: BE very circumſpect in the choice of your company; in the ſociety of your equals you may enjoy pleaſure; in the ſociety of your ſuperiors, you may find profit; but to be the beſt in company, is to be in the way of growing worſe; the beſt means to improve, is, to be the leaſt there. But above all, be the companion of thoſe who fear the Lord, and keep his precepts.

div.head: OF POVERTY.
div.p:
IN ſeeking virtue, if you find poverty, be not aſhamed, the fault is not yours. Your honour or diſhonour is purchaſed by your own actions; though virtue gives a ragged livery, ſhe gives a golden
cognizance. If her ſervice make you poor, bluſh not; your poverty may prove diſadvantageous to you, but cannot diſhonour you.

div.head: OF READING.
div.p: OF all the diverſions of life, there is none ſo proper to fill up its empty ſpaces, as the reading of uſeful and entertaining authors; and with that the converſation of a well choſen friend. By reading we enjoy the dead, by converſation the living, and by contemplation ourſelves. Reading enriches the memory, converſation poliſhes the wit, and contemplation improves the judgment. Of theſe reading is the moſt important, which furniſhes both the others.
